header.p: Here are some things I've been working on, as well as some stuff on the backburner.

description.p: The typical hacker will always be working on something, even if they haven't actually put any work into that something for years. Software projects are never complete.

listItem.columnValue: No hacker's page would be complete without a quip about self-reference!

Written entirely in C# and Lua using GTK#, I've designed this simulator to be as extensible and scriptable as possible. No graphics support -- backend only. I haven't worked much on this recently; still a lot of work that can be done though.

description.p: I currently live with my parents in a house that my father built. I've put a lot of work into this house over the years, along with my brothers, and of course my father.

listItem.columnValue: I built a bedroom and bathroom in my parents' basement back in 2008 with the help of my father. This is what I call my living space, along with the "den"--the "living room" of the basement.

The house needed a new roof. The old roof was over 20 years old, and leaked in a few places because of destructive ice dams throughout every winter. We replaced the worse half of the roof in fall 2011, and we finished the other half in spring 2012. We also raised the peak by about a foot, and continued the roof at a constant angle out to the soffet (unlike the previous design which used two different pitches, like a barn). This effectively removed the dormers from the bedrooms on the top floor of the house, adding a foot and a half to their outer footprint. We even have some attic space now, whereas there was barely room to crawl before.

My Hammond is a model RT-2. I stripped the pedal mechanisms and dismantled them, since they hardly worked, were needlessly heavy, and unnecessary. I built a custom cabinet for the guts of the organ (not pictured) and burned the old one. Someday I'll build another, prettier, lighter cabinet, because the aforementioned custom cabinet was put together in haste. I would like to rewire the tonewheels so the organ can be more portable, but that would be a massive undertaking.

When I bought this guitar, it looked like
this. I stripped off the tiger fur and painted it pink so that now it looks something like
this. I more recently rebuilt the electronics using Lace Sensor Gold pickups, and replaced the black pickguard with a white one. I want to repaint it once more and lacquer it. Someday I will replace the neck with a Fender Strat neck, then Pinkie will be a full-fledged strat.
